President Biden Emphasizes Unity, Democracy, and Hope in Inaugural Address

My fellow Americans, today is a day that celebrates the triumph of democracy and the resilience of our nation. As I stand before you, I am reminded of the countless individuals who have fought for the values we hold dear, the values that have brought us to this moment. Democracy's day has come, and democracy has prevailed.

In these challenging times, we must recognize the fragility of our democracy. Recent events have tested our resolve, but through it all, our democratic institutions have remained strong. The peaceful transfer of power is a testament to the enduring strength of our Constitution and the unity of our nation.

I am honored to stand here today, surrounded by the support of my predecessors, who have dedicated their lives to serving this great country. I salute President Jimmy Carter for his lifetime of service and his unwavering commitment to the American people.

As we confront the numerous challenges facing our nation - from the COVID-19 pandemic to economic struggles, racial injustice, climate change, and political extremism - we must come together as one nation. Unity is not just a nicety; it is a necessity for our future.

We must treat each other with dignity and respect, rejecting the divisive rhetoric that has plagued our political discourse. We must reject a culture of manipulated facts and instead embrace the truth as the foundation of our democracy.

I pledge to be a President for all Americans, regardless of political affiliation. Together, we can overcome the lies and misinformation that seek to divide us. Truth will be our guiding principle as we work towards a better future for all.

As we look ahead, let us not lose sight of the hope and resilience that defines the American spirit. We have faced challenges before, and we have emerged stronger each time. I believe in our ability to change, to grow, and to overcome whatever obstacles lie in our path.

Together, we can build a brighter future for our children and grandchildren. Let us stand united, guided by the principles of democracy, truth, and hope. The road ahead will not be easy, but with unity as our compass, we will navigate through these turbulent times and emerge stronger on the other side.

Thank you, God bless you, and may God bless the United States of America.

Fact Check: Claims of Flags Added to National Mall for Biden Inauguration Lack Context

The inauguration of President Joe Biden faced unique challenges this year due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and security threats following the storming of the U.S. Capitol earlier in the month. These limitations greatly affected the traditional aspects of the ceremony, including crowd sizes, guest attendance, and overall atmosphere.

To adhere to health guidelines and prevent the spread of COVID-19, crowd sizes at the inauguration were significantly limited. Attendees were required to wear masks and maintain social distancing throughout the event. These precautions were put in place to prioritize the safety and well-being of all participants during the historic occasion.

Former President Donald Trump notably declined to attend the inauguration, marking a break from long-standing tradition where outgoing presidents usually participate in the peaceful transfer of power. Trump's absence added a noteworthy element to the ceremony, indicating the political divide that has characterized his term in office.

Given the heightened security concerns in the wake of the Capitol riot, Washington D.C. saw an increase in security measures to safeguard the inauguration. Law enforcement agencies were out in full force to ensure the safety of those in attendance and to prevent any potential disruptions during the event.

In the lead-up to Inauguration Day, misinformation and false claims circulated widely, further complicating the already tense atmosphere. One such claim suggested that flags were strategically placed on the National Mall to create the illusion of a larger crowd and make the event look less empty. However, this claim lacked context.

The flags that adorned the National Mall were actually part of a public art exhibition symbolizing the Americans who were unable to attend the inauguration in person due to the pandemic and security concerns. This artistic representation was intended to honor those individuals and their presence in spirit during the event.

President Biden's team maintained strict coronavirus precautions throughout the inauguration, building on the practices implemented during his presidential campaign. This commitment to public health and safety underscored the administration's dedication to following scientific recommendations and leading by example in the face of a global health crisis.

The absence of large crowds at Biden's inauguration marked a significant departure from the typical celebratory atmosphere of past ceremonies. The subdued nature of the event reflected the challenging circumstances facing the nation and underscored the importance of unity and healing in the days ahead.

In conclusion, while claims that flags were added to the National Mall to fill space at the Biden inauguration do have some basis in truth, they fail to provide the full context of the health and security considerations that shaped the event. The use of flags as part of a symbolic art installation was a deliberate choice aimed at honoring absent Americans, rather than solely a tactic to mask reduced crowd sizes. It is crucial to consider all relevant factors when evaluating such claims to ensure an accurate understanding of the situation.

Historic Inauguration: Biden Sworn In Amid Tight Security

Washington CNN – President Joe Biden was sworn into office on Wednesday in a historic and heavily guarded inauguration ceremony at the U.S. Capitol. The event took place amidst a pandemic, with stringent security measures following the Capitol riot earlier this month, and notably, without the presence of outgoing President Donald Trump.

Donald Trump bid farewell to the White House for the last time as president, boarding Marine One and flying to Joint Base Andrews. In his address at the base, Trump reflected on his time in office, stating, "It is my greatest honor and privilege to have been your president." Despite not mentioning Joe Biden by name, he wished the incoming administration "great luck and great success."

Meanwhile, President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris began the day attending morning services at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle in Washington, joined by their families and Congressional leaders. Vice President Harris made history as the first female, first Black, and first South Asian vice president of the United States, marking a significant moment in American politics.

"I will be a president for all Americans," Joe Biden declared as he took the presidential oath, administered by Chief Justice John Roberts. Using a family Bible, Biden pledged unity and healing in a deeply divided nation, emphasizing the need to work together to overcome challenges.

The inauguration ceremony featured performances by top artists, including Lady Gaga, Jennifer Lopez, and Garth Brooks, who entertained the limited live audience present at the event. Amanda Gorman, the youngest inaugural poet in U.S. history, captivated viewers with her poem "The Hill We Climb."

Following the ceremony, President Biden wasted no time in getting to work, signing his first presidential documents, which included an Inauguration Day Proclamation and nominations for key positions in his administration. Biden also participated in a wreath-laying ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery, alongside Vice President Harris and former presidents.

In his early hours as president, Biden signed over a dozen executive actions, aiming to reverse some of his predecessor's policies. He emphasized the importance of respect and decency within the White House, directing staff to treat each other with dignity and work collaboratively towards common goals.

Former First Lady Melania Trump, in her farewell remarks, stated, "Being your First Lady was my greatest honor. Thank you for your support and inspiration." Melania, alongside Donald Trump, decided not to attend the inauguration, a break from tradition in the peaceful transition of power.

Looking ahead, President Joe Biden faces a myriad of challenges, from the ongoing pandemic to economic recovery and social unrest. With Vice President Kamala Harris by his side, Biden has pledged to lead the nation with empathy and a commitment to unity, hoping to heal the divides that have plagued the country in recent years.

As the world watches, the Biden administration begins its journey, determined to write a new chapter in American history, one characterized by resilience, compassion, and progress.

Biden Sworn in as 46th President, Calls for Unity in Unusual Inauguration

WASHINGTON (AP) – Joe Biden was inaugurated as the 46th President of the United States on Wednesday, emphasizing the triumph of democracy and calling for unity in a deeply divided nation. Kamala Harris also made history as the first woman, first Black person, and first person of South Asian descent to be sworn in as the Vice President.

The inauguration, taking place with heightened security and no crowds due to the dual threats of the pandemic and the recent siege on the Capitol, was a stark contrast to past ceremonies. Over 200,000 American flags were planted on the National Mall to represent those who were unable to attend the event.

In his inaugural address, Biden indirectly rebuked former President Donald Trump, focusing instead on themes of democracy, unity, and the challenges facing the country, such as the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, economic strain, and racial injustice. He called for Americans to come together to confront these issues.

On his first day in office, Biden wasted no time in signing a series of executive actions, including rejoining the Paris Climate Accords and instituting a mask mandate on federal property. These actions signaled his administration's commitment to addressing key issues from day one.

Former Presidents Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, and Barack Obama were in attendance, underscoring a rare show of bipartisan support for Biden as he assumes the presidency. The presence of these former leaders highlighted the peaceful transfer of power that is a cornerstone of American democracy.

Biden enters office with a clear plan for his first 100 days, which includes a strong focus on combating the COVID-19 pandemic and providing economic relief to those struggling in its wake. These early actions are intended to set the tone for his administration and demonstrate a commitment to fulfilling his campaign promises.

The inauguration ceremony featured performances by artists like Lady Gaga, who sang the national anthem, and others, all with a focus on national unity and healing. The absence of crowds and the large security presence served as a reminder of the challenges and divisions that Biden will confront as he takes on the presidency in these unprecedented times.

Amanda Gorman's Poem 'The Hill We Climb' Inspires Hope and Unity at Biden's Inauguration

Amanda Gorman, the nation's first-ever youth poet laureate, captivated audiences around the world with her powerful reading of "The Hill We Climb" during President Joe Biden's inauguration on January 20. The 22-year-old poet's stirring performance addressed themes of hope, unity, and resilience in the face of adversity, resonating with a country grappling with deep divisions and challenges.

In her poem, Gorman reflected on the struggles and triumphs of the United States, acknowledging the obstacles it has faced while envisioning a future defined by progress and inclusivity. She painted a vivid picture of a "skinny Black girl descended from slaves and raised by a single mother" harboring dreams of presidential aspirations, symbolizing the country's journey towards greater representation and equality.

Emphasizing the importance of coming together to overcome differences, Gorman highlighted the nation as "not broken, but simply unfinished." She called on Americans to strive towards a more perfect union, urging collective action and understanding as the pathways to positive change.

Gorman's poignant delivery and the content of her poem were met with widespread acclaim, with many commending her poise and eloquence during a historic moment for the country. Her recitation of "The Hill We Climb" symbolized a beacon of hope and renewal for countless Americans seeking unity and healing in a deeply divided nation.

"The Hill We Climb" echoed the themes of President Biden's inauguration, emphasizing resilience, unity, and the capacity for transformation that comes from shared purpose. By invoking images of progress and envisioning a future defined by inclusivity and understanding, Gorman's poem struck a chord with viewers across the political spectrum.

As the youngest inaugural poet in U.S. history, Gorman's presence and words resonated with audiences of all ages, offering a message of inspiration and strength during a time of uncertainty and change. Her call for unity and perseverance reverberated far beyond the inaugural stage, reminding Americans of the potential for progress when individuals come together in pursuit of a common goal.

In the aftermath of a contentious election and amid ongoing social and political challenges, Gorman's poem served as a unifying force, reminding Americans of the shared values that bind them together. By embracing the notion of an unfinished nation striving towards a more perfect union, she embodied the spirit of hope and possibility that defines the American experience.

Ultimately, Amanda Gorman's recitation of "The Hill We Climb" will be remembered as a defining moment in a historic presidential inauguration, a testament to the enduring power of poetry to inspire, comfort, and unite a nation in times of turmoil and triumph.

President Trump to Skip Biden Inauguration, Breaking Tradition

WASHINGTON (AP) – President Donald Trump announced on Friday that he will not be attending President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration on January 20th. This decision breaks from the longstanding tradition of a peaceful transition of power and is perceived as an act of defiance against the norms of American democracy.

Biden responded to Trump's decision by calling him an "embarrassment" and describing Trump's absence as a "good thing". Typically, the outgoing and incoming presidents attend the inauguration together, symbolizing a smooth transfer of power.

Notably, former Presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush, and Bill Clinton, with the exception of the ailing Jimmy Carter, have all confirmed their attendance at Biden's inauguration.

Trump's announcement came in the midst of discussions surrounding his potential second impeachment and shortly after he was permanently suspended from Twitter due to concerns about inciting violence.

Despite his loss in the 2020 election, Trump has continued to falsely claim victory and allege widespread voter fraud without presenting evidence to support his claims.

The attendance of Vice President Mike Pence at Biden's inauguration remains uncertain. Biden has expressed his desire for Pence to attend, extending a welcome to his predecessor.

Historian Douglas Brinkley remarked on Trump's decision, stating that his absence from the inauguration paints him as a "sore loser" and undermines the democratic process of a peaceful transfer of power.

Republican Senator Rick Scott of Florida commented on Trump's absence, stating that it is the president's decision whether to attend the inauguration and that the focus should be on a peaceful transition of power.

Devin O'Malley, a spokesperson for Vice President Pence, did not confirm whether Pence would attend the inauguration, stating that the vice president and his wife were still weighing their decision.

White House spokesperson Judd Deere defended Trump's decision, asserting that it follows his commitment to ensuring a smooth transition and allowing for a seamless transfer of power to the next administration.

Amidst concerns about Trump's actions in his final days in office, discussions about invoking the 25th Amendment or pursuing impeachment are ongoing in Congress, as lawmakers grapple with the fallout of the events at the Capitol and the president's role in them.

FBI Warns of Potential Armed Protests as Inauguration Nears

The FBI has issued a stark warning of possible armed protests in all 50 states and the US capital as the nation braces for President-elect Joe Biden's upcoming inauguration on January 20. State officials are on high alert, preparing for potentially violent demonstrations in support of outgoing President Donald Trump. National Guard forces have been activated in several states, including California, Michigan, Pennsylvania, Kentucky, and Florida, to ensure security in the face of potential threats.

In a troubling incident, a man named Wesley Allen Beeler was arrested at a security checkpoint near the US Capitol, found with a loaded handgun and over 500 rounds of ammunition. Beeler claimed his possession of the weapons was "an honest mistake," stating that he was a private security guard who had become lost. Despite his explanation, the incident has further raised concerns about security ahead of the inauguration.

The FBI's warning of potential violent protests at all 50 state capitol buildings starting on Saturday and through Biden's inauguration highlights the gravity of the situation. Additionally, the anti-government "Boogaloo" movement is reportedly planning rallies in all 50 states on Sunday, adding to the tension. State officials are implementing various security measures in response, such as closing the Texas Capitol and erecting a fence around the Michigan Capitol.

Thousands of armed National Guard troops have been deployed on the streets of Washington, DC, in preparation for the inauguration. Governor JB Pritzker of Illinois emphasized the seriousness of the situation, stating, "We will not allow any incidents of destruction or violence in our state." Meanwhile, Democratic leaders of several US congressional committees have opened a review of the January 6 riot at the US Capitol, seeking to understand the security failures that allowed the breach to occur.

In response to the escalating risks, Steve McCraw, Director of the Texas Department of Public Safety, affirmed, "We are working diligently with our partners to ensure the safety of the capitol complex and the public." Michigan State Police Director Joe Gasper echoed similar sentiments, underscoring the need for heightened vigilance during this critical period. Democratic Representative Don Beyer of Virginia stressed the importance of addressing the security concerns ahead of the inauguration, stating, "These domestic terrorists attacked the seat of American government, killed a police officer, and sought to overturn a democratic election."

House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff, House Homeland Security Chairman Bennie Thompson, House Oversight Chairwoman Carolyn Maloney, and House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler are leading the congressional review into the Capitol riot, aiming to comprehensively investigate the events and prevent future breaches of democracy. With tensions running high and the specter of violence looming, authorities across the country are taking decisive measures to safeguard the integrity of the democratic process and ensure a peaceful transition of power.

"Biden's Inauguration: Unity Amidst Tensions of Security Heightened by Fear"

As Joe Biden takes the oath of office, symbolizing a moment of national unity and the peaceful transfer of power, Washington stands on edge, bracing for potential violence amidst heightened security concerns. The backdrop of Biden's inauguration is shadowed by the looming threat of further MAGA violence following the Capitol attack on January 6, incited by Donald Trump. The FBI's warning of potential disruptions by QAnon followers, including plans to infiltrate as National Guard troops, has cast a cloud over the inauguration proceedings.

FBI Director Christopher Wray emphasized the need for vigilance against an array of threats, ranging from armed protests to lone wolf attacks, underscoring the delicate balance between security preparedness and democratic norms. The infiltration of insurrectionists posing as security forces only adds to the simmering tension over the transition of power, deepening concerns surrounding extremist involvement in law enforcement and the military. Individuals with military backgrounds were among the ranks of the MAGA extremists who stormed the Capitol, prompting a critical review of security measures for the inauguration.

In an effort to mitigate risks, the Pentagon has escalated its endeavors to purge far-right extremists from its ranks, aiming to uphold the integrity of security forces tasked with safeguarding democratic institutions. The removal of two Army National Guard members with ties to fringe right-wing militias from the inauguration security mission further spotlights the urgency in addressing this pressing issue. The unsettling reality that a robust security presence is required to protect the incoming president in the nation's capital echoes a poignant reminder that in a healthy democracy, such measures should not be the norm.

As the nation grapples with the aftermath of a turbulent transition and the looming specter of extremist threats, the imperative to fortify democratic principles and ensure the integrity of institutions remains paramount. The delicate balance between security imperatives and democratic values underscores the challenges that confront the nation as it navigates this pivotal moment in history.

Joe Biden Inaugurated as 46th US President, Vows to Uphold Constitution Amid Unprecedented Challenges

In a historic and solemn ceremony, Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th president of the United States, becoming the oldest president in the nation's history. With his hand on a family heirloom Bible, Biden took the oath of office, committing to preserve, protect, and defend the US Constitution. The inauguration, held amid a pandemic and heightened security concerns, was notably scaled-back, reflecting the challenges facing the country.

In a departure from tradition, former President Donald Trump chose not to attend Biden's inauguration or participate in the peaceful transfer of power. While Trump broke established norms, top Republicans and former Presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush, and Bill Clinton were present to witness the historic moment. Former President Jimmy Carter, unable to attend due to COVID-19 concerns, was notably absent but sent his best wishes.

Kamala Harris made history as she was sworn in as the first Black, first woman, and first Asian American vice president. Justice Sonia Sotomayor administered the oath using two Bibles, one of which belonged to Thurgood Marshall, the first African American Supreme Court Justice. The historic moment marked a significant step towards greater diversity and representation in the highest levels of American government.

The inauguration took place under tight security, with thousands of National Guard troops deployed following the violent insurrection at the US Capitol on January 6. The National Mall, typically filled with crowds during inaugurations, was instead adorned with nearly 200,000 flags and 56 pillars of light, symbolizing unity and representing the US states and territories.

The inauguration of Biden and Harris comes at a time of deep political divide, economic uncertainty, and a devastating pandemic that has claimed hundreds of thousands of American lives. As they assume office, the new administration faces the formidable task of bringing together a fractured nation, reviving the economy, and leading the country through one of the most challenging periods in recent history.

Dignitaries Gather for Biden Inauguration at Capitol

WASHINGTON – Dignitaries from across the political spectrum, including former presidents, lawmakers, and governors, have descended upon the Capitol for Joe Biden's inauguration as the 46th President of the United States. The ceremony is unfolding on a brisk but sunlit day, with the U.S. Marine Band setting the tone with its music.

Amid ongoing concerns about the COVID-19 pandemic, invited guests are seated in widely spaced chairs, adhering to safety protocols. Security measures are also notably tight around the Capitol, reflecting the heightened awareness of potential threats following the events of January 6.

Former President Barack Obama and South Carolina Rep. James Clyburn were spotted exchanging greetings as they took their seats in the socially distanced crowd. Congressional leaders and other notable figures have likewise assumed their positions on the platform for the historic event.

Notable personalities like Alex Rodriguez have also made an appearance, with Jennifer Lopez gearing up for a special performance at the ceremony. However, absent from the proceedings is former President Donald Trump, who breaks tradition as the first departing commander-in-chief since 1869 to skip his successor's swearing-in.

In contrast, Vice President Mike Pence and former President George W. Bush are among the Republicans present to witness the peaceful transfer of power. The only absence among the living former presidents is Jimmy Carter, who opted not to attend the event.

Reflecting on the significance of the day, former GOP senator Jeff Flake emphasized the importance of upholding the traditions of democracy and the peaceful transfer of power. Flake noted the symbolic weight of Biden's presidency and the need for unity in a deeply divided nation.

As the ceremony progresses, with dignitaries and guests in attendance, the inauguration of Joe Biden stands as a pivotal moment in American history, marking the beginning of a new chapter for the nation.

Lady Gaga's Schiaparelli Dress at Biden's Inauguration Becomes Iconic

Lady Gaga, the multihyphenate star known for her bold fashion choices, recently revealed that the Schiaparelli Haute Couture dress she wore at President Joe Biden's inauguration has become one of her all-time favorite outfits. The dress, which was featured in a British Vogue video showcasing 20 iconic looks from Gaga's career, stood out not only for its stunning design but also for its unique functionality. Gaga shared that the dress was actually bulletproof, adding an extra layer of significance to the ensemble.

Choosing to wear Schiaparelli, an Italian designer, was a personal choice for Gaga, reflecting her Italian-American heritage. The gown featured a giant gilded brooch in the shape of a dove, symbolizing peace, making it a powerful statement piece for the occasion. Daniel Roseberry, the creative director of Maison Schiaparelli, described the ensemble as a love letter to America, celebrating Gaga's artistry and the values she holds dear.

Before the inauguration, Gaga also made a memorable appearance in a white cape by Givenchy, drawing comparisons to Princess Leia with her regal and iconic look. For her singing performance, she wore a fitted navy cashmere jacket paired with a voluminous washed red silk faille skirt, creating a striking silhouette. Her hair was styled in a braid, similar to the previous day, but this time accented with a vibrant red flower, adding a touch of elegance to the overall look.

Daniel Roseberry's American background brings a unique perspective to the French brand Schiaparelli, bridging the gap between European couture and American creativity. With Gaga's fashion choices at the inauguration, including the memorable Schiaparelli dress, she not only showcased her impeccable style but also made a powerful statement about unity, peace, and the celebration of artistry on a global stage.

US Capitol complex locked down during Biden inauguration rehearsal

The US Capitol complex in Washington, DC, was briefly locked down earlier today during a rehearsal for President-elect Joe Biden's upcoming inauguration. The lockdown was initiated as a precautionary measure by the acting chief of Capitol Police following a fire in a homeless encampment located approximately 1.6 kilometres away from the Capitol building, raising security concerns in the area.

Though the fire caused some initial alarm, officials moved quickly to reassure the public that there was no direct threat to either the public or the upcoming inauguration from the incident. President-elect Joe Biden was not present at the rehearsal during the temporary lockdown, involving participants such as a military band who were directed to move to a secure location inside the Capitol complex.

The recent lockdown of the Capitol comes in the wake of heightened security concerns following the violent breach of the building by supporters of President Donald Trump on January 6. Security in and around the Capitol has been significantly increased, placing the area on high alert to prevent any potential disturbances throughout the presidential transition period.

The US Secret Service took to Twitter to confirm that the lockdown was a precautionary measure and to alleviate any fears by stating that there was no immediate threat to the public. Meanwhile, the fire department extinguished the fire near the Capitol, confirming that there were no injuries and providing clarity on the source of the smoke seen emanating from the encampment.

As Washington, DC, continues to prepare for President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration, security measures remain a top priority to ensure the safety of all involved. The incident today, while causing a temporary disruption, serves as a reminder of the ongoing vigilance and readiness to address any potential security threats effectively.

Security Tightens in Washington as 20,000 National Guard Members Prepare for Biden's Inauguration

Washington CNN – As the inauguration of President-elect Joe Biden nears, more than 20,000 National Guard members are expected to descend on Washington D.C. to fortify security measures and ensure a safe transition of power. The US Secret Service has assumed official responsibility for securing Biden's inauguration, with concerns mounting over potential unrest and the use of improvised explosive devices (IEDs) in the area.

FBI Director Chris Wray, alongside federal officials, has issued warnings regarding the presence of extremists at planned rallies and the potential for violence during the inauguration. Washington, DC Police Chief Robert Contee emphasized the necessity for heightened vigilance in the face of these threats. Security perimeters around key locations such as the Capitol, White House, and National Naval Observatory have been expanded to deter any security breaches.

The elaborate security operation surrounding Biden's inauguration involves close coordination among the Secret Service, various federal law enforcement agencies, and the Pentagon. The total request for National Guard support stands near 30,000, with an expected final deployment of around 20,000 troops. This staggering number of National Guard members surpasses the combined active-duty US troop presence in conflict zones like Afghanistan, Iraq, and Syria.

Ken Cuccinelli, a DHS Senior Official performing the duties of the Deputy Secretary, highlighted discussions within the administration about the potential elevation of the national terror threat level. With fears of escalated attacks following the breach of the Capitol, security measures are being amplified to confront any possible threats head-on. The Secret Service has been tasked with spearheading inauguration security efforts to mitigate the increased risk of violence during the transition of power.

"The FBI is tracking an extensive amount of concerning online chatter, including calls for armed protests leading up to Inauguration Day," stated FBI Director Chris Wray. The intelligence gathered points towards a significant risk of violence brewing among extremist groups who may seek to disrupt the inauguration proceedings. Washington, DC Police Chief Robert Contee emphasized the collaborative efforts underway to ensure the safety of all individuals attending the event.

To bolster security measures, the National Guard presence in Washington will be significantly reinforced, dwarfing the numbers deployed into active conflict zones overseas. The scale of military presence underlines the gravity of the security concerns facing the nation's capital ahead of Biden's inauguration. As the nation braces for a peaceful transfer of power, authorities are leaving no stone unturned to fortify security and prevent any potential threats from materializing.

Biden Inauguration Sees Enhanced Security Measures Amid Fear of Violence

WASHINGTON (AP) – In a tightly secured ceremony, Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th President of the United States on Wednesday, in a peaceful transition of power that starkly contrasted the chaos and violence of the Capitol riot just two weeks prior. Security concerns were at an all-time high following the attack by rioters loyal to former President Donald Trump, prompting authorities to take extensive precautions.

Law enforcement agencies closely monitored far-right extremist groups and militia organizations for any potential threats. Despite fears of armed protests and disruptions, the day unfolded without any major security incidents. Only a few scattered arrests were reported, and no significant protests materialized during the inauguration.

More than 25,000 National Guard troops and law enforcement officers were deployed in the nation's capital to secure the event. The entire National Mall was closed to the public, with multiple checkpoints manned by armed guards, and strict barricades set up around the Capitol and key government buildings.

Gen. Daniel Hokanson, chief of the National Guard Bureau, stated that the FBI conducted a thorough vetting of all 25,000 National Guard members involved in the security operation, in an unprecedented security measure to prevent any insider threats. Additionally, twelve National Guard members were removed from their duties after exhibiting extremist behavior or having ties to right-wing militia groups.

Federal agents were vigilant in monitoring concerning online chatter and possible attempts at infiltration by extremist elements. Despite the heightened security presence, no credible threats came to fruition. The lack of significant protests and incidents on Inauguration Day came as a relief to many who had feared a repeat of the violence seen at the Capitol earlier in January.

Online, followers of the QAnon conspiracy theory expressed disappointment as their predictions of a dramatic event to keep Trump in power failed to materialize. QAnon adherents had been anticipating a so-called "storm" where Trump would somehow remain in office and carry out mass arrests of his political opponents.

The massive security presence in Washington is expected to remain heightened for several days post-inauguration, as authorities remain on high alert for any potential threats or unrest. The peaceful transfer of power to the Biden administration brought a sense of normalcy back to the nation's capital, following weeks of political turmoil and division.

"Purple Reign: Symbolism of Unity and Royalty at Biden-Harris Inauguration"

The 59th Presidential Inauguration of President Joseph R. Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris was not only a historic moment in American politics but also a colorful display of symbolism. Among the sea of fashion choices that graced the event, the color purple stood out prominently, adorning prominent figures like Dr. Jill Biden, Kamala Harris, Michelle Obama, Hillary Clinton, Laura Bush, Amy Klobuchar, and Mike Pence.

Purple, a color traditionally associated with royalty, held deeper significance at the inauguration. It symbolized America's historical ties to monarchy while reflecting the country's innate yearning for its own form of nobility. Additionally, the color purple is synonymous with the Purple Heart, an esteemed military decoration awarded to those wounded or killed while serving in the U.S. Armed Forces. This nod to the sacrifices of military personnel added a layer of solemnity to the festivities.

Beyond its royal and military connotations, purple at the inauguration also embodied unity. By blending the colors of red (Republican) and blue (Democratic), the choice of purple sent a powerful message of bipartisan harmony and collaboration. This theme of unity was particularly poignant in a country deeply divided by political ideologies and partisan tensions.

The selection of purple at the inauguration also found resonance in literature, notably Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel 'The Color Purple'. The novel, which delves into the struggles of African American women, mirrored the groundbreaking nature of Harris's ascension to the Vice Presidency. Gwendolyn Dubois Shaw, Senior Historian at the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery, underscored the deep-rooted significance of purple in American democracy and notions of royalty.

In a time marred by political division and discord, the inauguration's purple motif served as a beacon of hope and a call for national unity. It stood in stark contrast to the red hats symbolizing the previous administration, symbolizing a new chapter and a fresh start for the country. The choice of purple transcended mere fashion statements, embodying political unity and social values that echoed far beyond the glamorous facade of the event.

Biden Arrives in DC for Inauguration, Faces Security Concerns

WASHINGTON (AP) – President-elect Joe Biden arrived in Washington D.C. from his home state of Delaware on the eve of his inauguration as the 46th president of the United States. Biden flew to Joint Base Andrews on a chartered plane, in contrast to President Donald Trump's government plane arrival in 2017. Security concerns prompted Biden to opt for flying instead of traveling by Amtrak, which he had often used during his political career.

Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris are scheduled to attend a COVID-19 memorial to honor the lives lost to the pandemic. Following the memorial, Biden will spend the night at Blair House, the presidential guest house. In a farewell address in Delaware, Biden emphasized his deep-rooted connection to the state, stating, "I'll always be a proud son of the state of Delaware."

Amid heightened security measures for the inauguration, 12 Army National Guard members have been removed from their duties after vetting by the FBI revealed ties to extremist views or right-wing militias. Gen. Daniel Hokanson, Chief of the National Guard, confirmed the members' removal, highlighting the importance of ensuring the security of the event.

Meanwhile, in his own farewell address, President Donald Trump stated, "I pray for the success of the new administration," a departure from his earlier stance on the election results. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell delivered a scathing rebuke of the departing president, accusing Trump of provoking the violent attack on the Capitol on January 6.

Three new Democratic senators are set to be sworn into office, effectively giving Democrats control of the Senate. This shift in power could have significant implications for Biden's legislative agenda moving forward. Despite concerns about security, no specific plot against Biden was identified as the reason for the removal of the two National Guard members.

As the nation prepares for a peaceful transition of power, with increased security measures in place, all eyes are on Washington D.C. for the historic inauguration of Joe Biden as the next President of the United States.

"A Scaled-Back Inauguration: Biden's Ceremony Adapts to COVID-19 and Security Concerns"

President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration, set to take place on January 20, 2021, will look notably different from past ceremonies as the country grapples with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and heightened security risks following the January 6th insurrection at the U.S. Capitol. In response to these challenges, organizers have arranged a series of scaled-back, heavily virtual events to mark the transition of power.

The Department's move suggests that inciting an attack on Congress is beyond the scope of employment for federal employees, including members of the House of Representatives, and could have significant implications for cases involving other officials linked to the Capitol riot.

Donald Ayer, a senior Justice Department official, stated that the decision not to defend Rep. Brooks could be seen as a message to Trump. He suggested that the move indicates that Trump may not be able to claim immunity under the Westfall Act for actions related to the Capitol siege.

Trump and Brooks are co-defendants in a lawsuit filed by Rep. Eric Swalwell, who accuses them of inciting the Capitol attack to prevent the certification of Joe Biden as president. This decision affects Trump's defense as he is facing two other lawsuits related to his actions surrounding the Capitol riot.

Jesse Binnall, Trump's attorney, has not yet sought protection from the Justice Department. Binnall's primary defense strategy does not rely on the Westfall Act but rather on presidential immunity.

Anne Tindall, an attorney at Protect Democracy, sees the Justice Department's actions as safeguarding the office of the presidency rather than offering personal protection to Trump. However, the refusal to defend Brooks may indicate a more stringent approach towards Trump.

Legal experts believe that Brooks' failed attempt to use the Westfall Act for immunity could signal challenges ahead for Trump. They anticipate that Trump's case could be weaker than Brooks' as Trump did not have an official role in the election certification process.

Some Democrats have expressed concern over the Justice Department's stance, fearing that it could provide an opening for Trump to avoid accountability. However, others view this as a sign of holding individuals accountable for their actions, regardless of their positions.

The refusal to defend Rep. Brooks in the lawsuit alleging incitement of the Capitol attack highlights the potential legal hurdles that Trump may face in similar cases. Legal analysts suggest that this recent development could spell trouble for Trump as he navigates his defense strategy in the ongoing lawsuits.

Ivey had traveled to Washington, D.C., for the event with his wife and brother, although only he had entered the Capitol building.

A sentencing hearing for Ivey is scheduled for Sept. 28, where he could potentially receive up to six months in prison, a $5,000 fine, and/or up to one year of probation. Robert David Baker, Ivey's Middle Tennessee public defender, plans to present mitigating factors in his client's defense during the upcoming proceedings.

Ivey's guilty plea marks him as the first defendant with Tennessee ties to admit involvement in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, underscoring the ongoing legal repercussions faced by individuals connected to the event.

Citibank loses legal battle over accidental $900 million transfer to Revlon's lenders

New York CNN Business – Citibank's accidental transfer of nearly $900 million to Revlon's lenders has sparked a legal battle with significant implications. The banking giant mistakenly wired almost $900 million to Revlon's lenders, instead of the intended $8 million in interest payments, due to a costly error. However, a US District Court judge has ruled that Citibank cannot recover the almost half a billion dollars that was not returned by some of the lenders.

The accidental transfer, which included $175 million going to a hedge fund, has left a total of $500 million still unrecovered from 10 investment advisory firms. Benjamin Finestone, who represented two lenders involved, Brigade and HPS Investment Partners, highlighted the complex nature of the case. The mix-up occurred when Citibank intended to send out interest payments on Revlon loans but mistakenly transferred a much larger sum.

Under New York law, there is a "discharge-for-value-defense" that allows beneficiaries to keep the money if they were entitled to it and were not aware that it was sent accidentally. In this case, Revlon's lenders believed that the massive payment was an intentional prepayment of a loan, aligning with the amounts Citibank owed them. The court sided with the lenders, justifying their belief that the payment was intentional, citing Citibank's sophistication in the financial industry making a mistake seem highly improbable.

Moreover, internal chats from HPS employees that joked about the error were used as evidence that they were unaware the wiring was a mistake, further strengthening the lenders' case. The situation has led to a temporary restraining order preventing the lenders from utilizing the funds to allow for a potential appeal process.

Citigroup, on the other hand, strongly disagrees with the court's decision and fully intends to appeal the ruling. The banking institution is determined to recover the entire amount that was mistakenly transferred. The ongoing legal battle sheds light on the complexities and potential consequences of such significant financial errors within the banking sector.

The backdrop of this case is set against the backdrop of the ongoing pandemic, which has had a detrimental impact on companies in the beauty industry, including makeup brands like Revlon. Revlon's shares are currently trading over 40% lower than they were a year ago, reflecting the challenges faced by the company in a changing economic landscape.

The fallout from Citibank's accidental transfer of nearly $900 million to Revlon's lenders continues to unfold, with legal battles and appeals expected to dominate the narrative in the coming months. The implications of this case reach far beyond the immediate parties involved, highlighting the importance of precision and accountability in high-stakes financial transactions.

According to reports, a subcontractor in India made the critical mistake by incorrectly checking boxes during the setup of the transaction. This oversight led to the unprecedented $500 million transfer, a sum that Citigroup has been unsuccessful in recouping from the creditors.

A federal judge, Jesse Furman, recently ruled that Citigroup is not entitled to recover the erroneously sent funds from the recipients. The judge highlighted the importance of implementing measures to minimize the risks of errors in financial transactions and hoped that other banks would learn from this high-profile case.

On the other hand, a spokesperson for Oracle, the provider of the Flexcube interface, refrained from providing any comments on the matter.

Ultimately, the judge's ruling was based on legal precedent and concluded that it was reasonable for the creditors to retain the funds received in error. This decision serves as a cautionary tale for financial institutions worldwide to prioritize robust controls and user-friendly interfaces in their banking systems to avoid costly mistakes like Citigroup's $500 million blunder.

The ECB also aims to sustain a balance level at least until the end of 2023. Concurrently, other ECB initiatives such as the Targeted Longer-Term Refinancing Operations (TLTRO III) and the Asset Purchase Program (APP) will carry on as scheduled.

The ECB's total asset balance has now reached approximately €8.2 trillion, predominantly composed of bonds and loans to banks. Central banks across the globe concur that winding down QE programs is imperative before contemplating hiking interest rates to avert any disruptions in the yield curve.

Despite this, the Federal Reserve continues to expand its balance sheet by $120 billion each month, even as there is a consensus among policymakers about the necessity to commence tapering this year. Christine Lagarde emphasized the unanimous decision within the ECB to recalibrate asset purchases, recognizing the importance of navigating the exit from QE smoothly and without destabilizing the Eurozone.

In a statement, President Lagarde said, "The recalibration of our monetary policy instruments reflects the improved medium-term inflation outlook and is designed to avoid abrupt adjustments that could jeopardize the ongoing economic recovery and the medium-term inflation outlook."

The ECB's proactive stance in aligning its policies with the changing economic landscape, along with the coordinated efforts of global central banks, aims to ensure a gradual and steady transition away from the extraordinary measures implemented during the height of the pandemic while ensuring stability and growth in the Eurozone economy.

Fact Check: False Claim of Bill Clinton's Death at Guantanamo Bay Circulates Amid Hospitalization for Sepsis

Former President Bill Clinton recently made headlines after being hospitalized in California for a non-COVID-related infection, specifically sepsis. However, a false claim circulating on social media suggested that Clinton had been poisoned to death at Guantanamo Bay, which has been debunked by reliable sources.

The misinformation claiming Clinton's death was part of a broader pattern of fabricated stories about high-profile figures, often linked to the baseless QAnon conspiracy theory. This particular false claim originated from Real Raw News, a website known for publishing fake stories and conspiracy theories.

Angel Ureña, a spokesperson for Bill Clinton, confirmed that the former president was in California receiving medical treatment and was now back in New York. Ureña provided reassurance about Clinton's condition, stating that his health was improving, and he was in excellent spirits.

Contrary to the false reports, Clinton was neither poisoned to death nor involved in any suspicious activities at Guantanamo Bay. Dawn Grimes, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Naval Hospital in Guantanamo Bay, refuted the claims made by Real Raw News. Grimes specifically denied any involvement of a U.S. Naval Hospital officer named Capt. Dale Ramirez in overseeing an autopsy of Bill Clinton.

Real Raw News, the source of the fake news, includes a disclaimer on its website stating that its content contains humor, parody, and satire. However, the disclaimer is not prominently displayed and is hidden on the about page, potentially leading some readers to believe the false stories are true.

PolitiFact conducted a fact-checking investigation and found that these fabricated stories are attributed to Michael Ruffin, who writes under the pseudonym Michael Baxter. Despite the satire disclaimer on Real Raw News, Ruffin stands by the accuracy of his stories, causing confusion among readers.

It is essential for the public to exercise caution and verify information from credible sources before sharing or believing stories that seem questionable. The spread of false information can have real-life consequences and can harm the reputation and well-being of individuals like Bill Clinton, who was falsely reported as deceased.

In conclusion, the claim of Bill Clinton's death at Guantanamo Bay due to poisoning is unequivocally false. Clinton's hospitalization in California for sepsis is unrelated to any nefarious activities at the notorious military base. It is crucial to rely on trustworthy sources and fact-check information to combat the spread of fake news and conspiracy theories.

Study Finds Colonial Pipeline Shutdown's Impact on Gas Prices Less Than Expected

LAWRENCE – The recent ransomware attack on the Colonial Pipeline, which caused the largest fuel pipeline in the U.S. to be shut down for six days, had a smaller impact on gas prices than originally feared, according to a new study.

Associate Professor Tsvetan Tsvetanov and doctoral student Srishti Slaria from the University of Kansas co-authored an article assessing the economic ramifications of the pipeline shutdown on gasoline prices. Their findings revealed that the actual impact on gas prices was significantly less than what was initially reported by the media.

"Our study found that the shutdown of the Colonial Pipeline led to just a 4-cents-per-gallon increase in average gasoline prices in the affected areas," said Tsvetan Tsvetanov, Associate Professor of Economics at the University of Kansas.

The study utilized daily regular gasoline price data at the city level and employed a difference-in-differences approach to evaluate the impact of the pipeline shutdown on prices.

The Colonial Pipeline, capable of carrying 3 million barrels of fuel per day between Texas and New York, plays a crucial role in supplying fuel to the East Coast and the Southeastern United States. The cyberattack on the pipeline by Russia-linked cybercriminals disrupted fuel supply chains, leading to concerns about potential spikes in gas prices.

"The demand for gasoline in the U.S. is described as 'inelastic,' meaning that consumption doesn't fluctuate significantly even as prices rise," explained Srishti Slaria, doctoral student at the University of Kansas.

Tsvetanov's research focusing on the economic implications of cybercrime is an emerging area of study. The study on the Colonial Pipeline shutdown serves to highlight the growing threat of cyberattacks on critical infrastructure and the energy sector.

Following the ransomware attack, Colonial Pipeline paid a $4.4 million ransom in Bitcoin to the hackers. However, the Justice Department was able to recover $2.3 million of the ransom, underscoring the complex legal and cybersecurity issues surrounding such incidents.

Tsvetanov's work aims to raise awareness about the intersection of cybersecurity and economics in the energy sector, emphasizing the importance of addressing cybersecurity risks in critical infrastructure to prevent future disruptions.

Fact Check: Republicans' Claims Blaming Biden for Gas and Lumber Costs Are Misleading

WASHINGTON (AP) – House Republican leaders have recently pointed fingers at President Joe Biden, accusing his policies of driving up gasoline and lumber costs in the United States. However, a closer look at the facts reveals that these assertions are misleading and not entirely based on reality.

The recent spike in gas prices is not because of Biden's policies, as House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy suggested. The primary reason for the increase in gas prices can be traced back to the cyberattack on the Colonial Pipeline, which disrupted fuel supplies along the East Coast. This cyberattack, not Biden's actions, led to temporary shortages and price hikes at the pump.

Furthermore, the current shortages and price increases in various sectors, including lumber, are mainly a result of the challenges in restarting the U.S. and global economies after the devastating impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. These difficulties are not solely the consequence of Biden's policy decisions.

Claims connecting Biden's cancellation of the Keystone XL pipeline to the current gasoline prices are also misleading. It's important to note that the Keystone XL pipeline was designed to transport crude oil, not gasoline. Therefore, any impact on gasoline prices from the cancellation would be indirect at best.

Gas prices have risen due to a rapid rebound in demand as pandemic restrictions ease and people resume travel. "Prices at the pump have been driven by the colonial pipeline shutdown that led to a brief spike in prices," said Patrick DeHaan, head of petroleum analysis for GasBuddy.

Comparing current gas prices with those from last year can be misleading, as gas prices in 2020 plummeted due to the global economic slowdown caused by the pandemic, not because of the policies of the Trump administration.

Despite the Colonial Pipeline being back in operation, some states are still experiencing gas shortages following the cyberattack. The disruptions caused by the attack continue to impact fuel supplies in certain areas, which is contributing to the lingering effects on gas prices.

Turning to lumber prices, the surge in costs can be attributed to increased demand and a sharp economic rebound, not Biden's policies as implied by some Republicans. "The lumber situation is completely based on a massive surge in demand with the pandemic placing enormous restrictions on how many people could work at building sites," noted Rep. Liz Cheney of Wyoming.

The accusation made by Ronna McDaniel, head of the Republican National Committee, that Biden's policies are responsible for a 400% increase in lumber prices is unfounded. Rising prices in commodities like lumber are partly due to strong consumer demand for goods, which is actually a positive sign indicating a recovering economy.

In conclusion, while there are legitimate concerns about rising costs in various sectors, direct blame solely on President Biden's policies is not supported by the facts. The true reasons behind the increases in gas and lumber prices are multifaceted and largely tied to the challenges experienced during the economic recovery post-pandemic.

Biden Announces Sweeping Federal Vaccine Mandates Affecting Millions

WASHINGTON (AP) – President Joe Biden unveiled a series of new federal vaccine mandates on Thursday, aiming to combat the surge in COVID-19 cases driven by the highly contagious delta variant. The mandates are expected to impact up to 100 million Americans across various sectors of the workforce.

The new rules, the most comprehensive to date by the Biden administration, will require private-sector employees, healthcare workers, federal contractors, and others to get vaccinated against COVID-19. During his address, Biden took a firm stance against the growing number of unvaccinated Americans, attributing the current surge in cases to their refusal to get vaccinated.

"The unvaccinated overcrowd our hospitals, are overrunning the emergency rooms, and intensive care units, leaving no room for someone with a heart attack or pancreatitis or cancer," Biden stated. "Their refusal has cost all of us."

However, the mandates have sparked criticism from Republican leaders who accused Biden of overreach and infringing on constitutional rights. Gov. Henry McMaster of South Carolina condemned the President's actions, calling them "a hideous assault on our liberty."

On the other hand, the American Medical Association, the National Association of Manufacturers, and the Business Roundtable voiced their support for the new mandates, applauding Biden's efforts to increase vaccination rates and curb the spread of the virus.

The new requirements will compel employers with more than 100 workers to mandate vaccines or implement weekly testing, affecting approximately 80 million Americans. Additionally, all employees of the executive branch and contractors working with the federal government will be required to be vaccinated, with no testing alternative, impacting several million more workers.

National President of the American Federation of Government Employees, Everett Kelley, expressed concerns over the mandate affecting federal workers, stating, "While we strongly encourage everyone to be vaccinated as the best way to combat the spread of this virus, we cannot support mandated vaccinations for federal employees without negotiating the matter with our bargaining units across the government."

In his address, Biden also outlined plans to ramp up virus testing, provide support for safe school operations, and urged large venues to mandate vaccinations or negative tests for entry. The President emphasized that the new rules would be enforced through various federal agencies, each responsible for implementing penalties and guidelines to ensure compliance.

Despite the U.S. having a relatively high vaccination rate compared to many countries, the nation is currently experiencing a concerning surge in COVID-19 infections, hospitalizations, and deaths, particularly among the unvaccinated population.

In response to the rising cases, many states have taken their own measures to increase vaccinations and mitigate the spread of the virus. Governor McMaster of South Carolina signed an executive order earlier this week banning mask mandates in schools, emphasizing the importance of personal choice in healthcare decisions.

White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki defended Biden's decision, reiterating the administration's commitment to fighting the pandemic. Psaki stated, "We know that increasing vaccinations will stop the spread of the pandemic, will get the pandemic under control, will return people to normal life."

As the nation grapples with the delta variant and its repercussions, the debate over vaccine mandates continues, with implications for public health, individual freedoms, and the trajectory of the pandemic in the United States.

FDA Authorizes COVID-19 Booster Doses for Individuals 18 Years and Older

In a significant move, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has expanded the eligibility for COVID-19 booster doses to include individuals 18 years and older who have completed their primary vaccination with any FDA-authorized or approved COVID-19 vaccine. This decision comes as the nation continues its fight against the pandemic, aiming to bolster immunity levels among the population.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's (CDC) Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices is set to convene and delve into further clinical recommendations regarding the expanded eligibility for booster doses. Acting FDA Commissioner Janet Woodcock, M.D., underlines the importance of COVID-19 vaccines as a highly effective defense against the virus, emphasizing the critical role boosters play in enhancing immunity.

Previously, booster dose authorization had been limited to older adults, high-risk individuals, and those with frequent exposure to COVID-19. Peter Marks, M.D., Ph.D., Director of the FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research, highlights the FDA's commitment to simplifying eligibility criteria and providing clear guidance on the availability of booster doses to the broader population.

The Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) for booster doses of the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccines is based on a comprehensive analysis of immune response data. Studies have shown that completing the primary vaccination series generates strong, sustained, and broadly neutralizing antibodies that offer significant protection against the virus.

It is anticipated that these vaccines will provide nearly 100% protection against secondary challenges posed by the current pandemic strain, further underscoring the importance of vaccination in the ongoing efforts to curb the spread of COVID-19. Both the FDA and CDC stress the critical need for vaccinations and adherence to precautions aimed at combatting not only COVID-19 but also other respiratory pathogens.

As the nation navigates the complexities of the pandemic, the authorization of COVID-19 booster doses for individuals 18 years and older marks a pivotal step towards enhancing population immunity. The FDA and CDC continue to work in tandem to promote vaccination efforts and safeguard public health in the face of evolving challenges.

State Data Shows Breakthrough COVID-19 Cases Among Vaccinated Individuals Are Rare

COVID-19 vaccines have been proven highly effective in preventing severe illness and death caused by the virus. However, breakthrough cases - where fully vaccinated individuals still contract the virus - do occur. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) closely monitors hospitalizations and deaths among the fully vaccinated population but does not track all breakthrough infections.

To gain a comprehensive understanding of breakthrough cases, hospitalizations, and deaths in vaccinated individuals, researchers reviewed data from official state sources for all 50 states and the District of Columbia. They found that not all hospitalizations and deaths reported in fully vaccinated individuals are directly caused by COVID-19.

While half of the states report data on COVID-19 breakthrough events, the frequency and level of detail in reporting vary across states. Despite this variability, the data indicates that breakthrough cases, hospitalizations, and deaths among the fully vaccinated are exceedingly rare. Rates of breakthrough cases among vaccinated individuals were below 1% in all states that provided reporting.

The majority of COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths continue to occur among unvaccinated or not fully vaccinated individuals. More than 90% of these severe outcomes are seen in those who have not completed their vaccination series or chosen not to get vaccinated at all.

State-level data underscores the rarity of COVID-19 breakthrough events among the fully vaccinated population in the United States. These findings provide strong support for the effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines in preventing severe illness and death. Robust and consistent state-level data is crucial for monitoring vaccine effectiveness and understanding the impact of breakthrough cases on vaccinated individuals.

The data reaffirm the importance of vaccination in protecting individuals and communities from the worst outcomes of COVID-19. While breakthrough infections can occur, the incidence of severe illness and death among fully vaccinated individuals remains very low. Public health officials continue to encourage vaccination as a key tool in controlling the spread of the virus and reducing its impact on society.

As the fight against COVID-19 continues, ongoing surveillance and analysis of breakthrough cases will be essential in evaluating vaccine effectiveness and informing public health strategies. The state-level data presented in this study serves as a valuable resource in demonstrating the overall effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines and reinforcing the importance of widespread vaccination efforts.

FDA Warns Against Altering COVID-19 Vaccine Dosing Schedules Without Sufficient Evidence

The FDA is pleased to report that two mRNA COVID-19 vaccines have demonstrated significant effectiveness in preventing the disease in adults, with efficacy rates of approximately 95%. The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine requires a 21-day interval between doses, while the Moderna vaccine requires 28 days. These vaccines represent a crucial tool in combating the ongoing pandemic, offering hope for a return to normalcy.

In light of recent discussions regarding potential alterations to vaccine dosing schedules or mixing different vaccines, the FDA underscores the importance of adhering to the authorized dosing regimens for COVID-19 vaccines. While exploring different dosing approaches is a natural part of scientific inquiry, any deviations from the authorized schedules without solid data can pose substantial risks to public health.

It is crucial to understand that changing the authorized dosing schedule without adequate evidence may not only compromise the vaccines' effectiveness but also potentially impact their safety. Misinterpretation of data related to a single dose's efficacy could lead to unwarranted assumptions about the level of protection provided. Without a comprehensive understanding of the protection depth and duration conferred by alternative dosing regimens, there is a risk of unintentionally diminishing the vaccines' benefits.

The FDA remains focused on making data-driven decisions and emphasizes that any considerations regarding altering vaccine dosing schedules must be firmly rooted in sound scientific evidence. Speculation or premature actions in this realm could have far-reaching implications for public health outcomes and jeopardize the progress made in controlling the pandemic. Therefore, it is imperative that decisions surrounding vaccine dosing continue to be guided by rigorous research and factual data.

Healthcare providers play a critical role in ensuring the safe and effective use of COVID-19 vaccines. The FDA strongly recommends that providers adhere to the authorized dosing schedules for the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines. By following these established protocols, healthcare professionals can help maximize the vaccines' protective benefits and minimize potential risks to individuals and communities.

As the nation's regulatory agency responsible for overseeing the safety and efficacy of drugs, vaccines, and other biological products, the FDA is committed to upholding the highest standards in public health protection. The agency will continue to evaluate new data and emerging research to inform decisions related to COVID-19 vaccines, always prioritizing the well-being of the public. In this critical time, the FDA urges all stakeholders to prioritize science, data, and evidence-based practices in the ongoing fight against the pandemic.

FDA and CDC Lift Recommended Pause on Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 Vaccine in the U.S.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have announced the lifting of the recommended pause on the use of the Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) COVID-19 vaccine in the United States following a thorough safety review. This decision comes after the agencies initially recommended the pause in the administration of the vaccine due to six reported cases of a rare and severe type of blood clot known as thrombosis-thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS).

During the temporary pause, medical and scientific teams within the FDA and CDC conducted a comprehensive review of the available data, assessed the potential risks associated with the vaccine, and engaged in outreach efforts to healthcare providers to ensure they were informed about the situation.

Dr. Janet Woodcock, Acting FDA Commissioner, emphasized that the safety of vaccines remains a top priority, stating, "We have concluded that the known and potential benefits of the Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine outweigh its known and potential risks in individuals 18 years of age and older." She also highlighted the robust monitoring systems in place to continue assessing the vaccine's safety.

According to the updated guidance, the data suggest that the risk of developing TTS after receiving the Johnson & Johnson vaccine is very low. Individuals who receive the vaccine, as well as healthcare providers administering it, are encouraged to review the revised fact sheets, which now include information on the risk of TTS.

The CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) has reviewed the latest data related to TTS and the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, CDC Director, underlined the effectiveness of the vaccine safety monitoring systems in place and encouraged individuals to consult with their healthcare providers if they have any questions or concerns about the vaccine.

Dr. Walensky stated, "The ACIP has reviewed the latest data and recommends that the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine be used for persons 18 years of age and older in the United States population under the FDA's Emergency Use Authorization." She emphasized the importance of continuing to monitor the safety of all COVID-19 vaccines.

Since the authorization of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, a total of 15 cases of TTS have been reported to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS), all of which were in women aged between 18 and 59 years. The agencies will continue to monitor reports of adverse events closely and take action as necessary.

In conclusion, the FDA and CDC are confident in the safety and efficacy of the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine and have lifted the recommended pause on its use. Individuals are encouraged to get vaccinated to protect themselves and their communities from the spread of COVID-19, and healthcare providers are urged to educate their patients about the benefits and risks of vaccination.

For more information, individuals can visit the FDA and CDC websites or speak to their healthcare providers. The agencies will continue to closely monitor the safety of all authorized COVID-19 vaccines and provide updates as needed.

Vaccine Uptake Among Children and Teens Stalls as Parents Express Concerns

Despite this, pediatricians remain the most trusted source of vaccine information for parents. However, fewer than half of parents have discussed COVID-19 vaccinations with their child's healthcare provider, pointing to a potential gap in communication and education.

Approximately half of parents report that their child's school provided information or encouraged COVID-19 vaccination, which appears to have an impact on vaccination rates. Parents whose schools actively promoted COVID-19 vaccination are more likely to have vaccinated children. Nevertheless, when it comes to the debate around schools requiring COVID-19 vaccines for eligible students, parents of 5-17 year-olds largely oppose such mandates, preferring personal choice over collective responsibility.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had lasting effects on parents and families across the board, particularly in areas such as mental health, financial stability, and children's education. These impacts are more pronounced among lower-income and minority groups, exacerbating existing disparities. As parents navigate these challenges, their decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccination for their children are influenced by a complex interplay of factors, including access to information, trust in healthcare providers, and broader societal beliefs.

As efforts continue to increase vaccination rates among children and teens, it is clear that a multifaceted approach encompassing targeted outreach to underserved communities, improved access to healthcare resources, and enhanced communication between parents, schools, and healthcare providers is needed. Addressing concerns about safety, side effects, and access barriers will be essential in building trust and increasing uptake. Ultimately, ensuring the health and well-being of children and families requires a collective effort from all stakeholders involved.

NIH Press Release: AstraZeneca's AZD1222 Vaccine Shows High Efficacy in Preventing COVID-19 Symptom and Severe Disease

AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine, AZD1222, has demonstrated significant efficacy in preventing symptomatic COVID-19 infections as well as severe disease or hospitalization. According to data from the clinical trial funded by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) and the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA), the vaccine showed a 78.9% efficacy rate in preventing symptomatic COVID-19 and a remarkable 100% efficacy in preventing severe disease or hospitalization.

The trial enrolled 32,449 adult volunteers across the United States, Chile, and Peru, with 20,000 individuals receiving the AZD1222 vaccine. "These results are very promising and demonstrate the vaccine's ability to provide substantial protection against COVID-19," stated Ann R. Falsey, M.D., Professor of Medicine at the University of Rochester School of Medicine in New York.

AZD1222 was well-tolerated among participants, with no safety concerns identified by the independent Data and Safety Monitoring Board. The vaccine's efficacy was consistent across different ethnicities, and it was found to be effective in participants 65 years and older. "The high efficacy rates and safety profile of the AZD1222 vaccine are encouraging and bode well for its potential as a key tool in the fight against the pandemic," commented Magdalena E. Sobieszczyk, M.D., Associate Professor of Medicine at Columbia University Medical Center in New York.

Importantly, there was no increased risk of thrombotic events or cerebral venous sinus thrombosis observed among vaccinated participants. This finding further supports the safety profile of the AZD1222 vaccine. The World Health Organization has recommended the use of the vaccine, which is currently available in over 70 countries worldwide.

AZD1222 utilizes a non-replicating chimpanzee adenovirus to deliver the genetic code of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein to human cells, triggering an immune response. The COVID-19 Prevention Network (CoVPN) played a critical role in enrolling volunteers for the clinical trial, which will continue to follow participants for about two years after their second injection to gather additional data for further study.

The impressive efficacy rates, safety profile, and widespread availability of the AZD1222 vaccine make it a valuable asset in the global efforts to combat COVID-19 and bring an end to the pandemic.

FDA Authorizes Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine for Children Ages 5-11

This decision comes as a result of comprehensive evaluation and determination of its safety and effectiveness in this younger age group in preventing COVID-19. A critical aspect of the evaluation was the safety profile of the vaccine, which was studied in approximately 3,100 children aged 5 through 11. No serious side effects were detected during the evaluation period. This reassures parents and healthcare providers of the vaccine's safety for this age group.

Dr. Peter Marks, Director of the FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research, emphasized, "The FDA's authorization is based on robust data that demonstrates the vaccine's efficacy and safety in children aged 5 through 11. We are committed to upholding the highest standards in evaluating vaccines for emergency use authorization."

Next week, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) will convene to discuss further recommendations regarding the use of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine for children aged 5 through 11.
